text: Billy Roche's greatest accomplishment is his work on his masterplan of the modern university in Paris, which he wrote and published in the 1960s. It is a plan for a "universal university" with a faculty, a student body, and a campus, which he called "a university for all humanity." Billy Roche's greatest accomplishment is the construction of the first hospital in Paris in 1849 (the first in the world). He was a pioneer in the field of surgery and was responsible for the founding of the Parisian hospital in the 19th century. Roche's work was also responsible for the creation of the Parisian hospital system, which today is a model hospital system. Billy Roche works as a general surgeon in Paris and is one of the great innovators in the history of medicine. He has been a pioneer in transplanting organs and tissue, as well as developing a variety of new surgical techniques. He was born in 1845 in the small Swiss town of La Chaux-de-Fonds to a wealthy Jewish family. His father, Joseph Roche, was a prominent lawyer and politician. Roche's mother was a devout Catholic. Billy Roche's greatest accomplishment is his role as architect of modern medical care. His contribution to medicine was to develop a system for the management of the sick that would be both effective and affordable. His innovations in medicine, and the way that the medical profession has adapted to them, have transformed the lives of millions. Billy Roche works as a consultant for the US Army and is credited with inventing the concept of modern medicine. In the early 1950s he was asked what it was that made medicine so special. "I told them that medicine is a science of living," he said. "The patient is a person and the doctor is the person that heals him.
